User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the LinguaStream application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

Video.title: Video
Video.description: Represents a YouTube video that the user has interacted with.

id.description: Unique identifier for the video entity.

youtubeUrl.description: The URL of the YouTube video.

title.description: The title of the YouTube video.

Transcript.title: Transcript
Transcript.description: Represents the transcript of a YouTube video.

id.description: Unique identifier for the transcript entity.

content.description: The full text content of the video transcript as an array of segments.

Vocabulary.title: Vocabulary
Vocabulary.description: Represents a custom vocabulary list created by the user for a specific video.

id.description: Unique identifier for the vocabulary entity.

Quiz.title: Quiz
Quiz.description: Represents a quiz for a video, including user answers and score for a specific attempt.

id.description: The unique identifier for the quiz.

videoId.description: The ID of the video this quiz belongs to.

userId.description: The ID of the user who took the quiz.

questions.description: A list of questions in the quiz.

correctAnswer.description: The correct answer from the options list.

score.description: The user's score (number of correct answers) for this quiz attempt. Optional.

userAnswers.description: The user's selected answers for each question. The index corresponds to the questions array. Optional.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to ensure data isolation and facilitate secure access based on user ownership. Each user has their own collection of videos, transcripts, quizzes, and vocabularies, eliminating the need for complex authorization rules. This structure adheres to the principles of Authorization Independence and Structural Segregation. Specifically:

1.  **Authorization Independence:** The design focuses on path-based ownership for all user-related data (videos, transcripts, quizzes, vocabularies). This eliminates the need for `get()` calls in security rules because access control is directly tied to the path. This allows atomic operations and simplifies debugging.

2.  **Structural Segregation:**  Each user's data is stored under their own document ID (`/users/{userId}`).  This ensures that all documents within a given collection share the same security requirements.  This simplifies security rules because they can be applied to entire collections rather than requiring filtering based on document content.

3.  **QAPs (Rules are not Filters):** The structure supports secure `list` operations because each user's resources are isolated within their own path. A user can list their videos, transcripts, and vocabularies without exposing data from other users.

4.  **Access Modeling:** All data is modeled using Path-Based ownership, which directly represents the `User 1:N Entity` relationships.

This design prioritizes clarity, security, and scalability by leveraging Firestore's hierarchical data model and enforcing strict ownership.
